Deodhar]] |align=center|Hindus, Maharashtra |14 January 1892 |24 August 1993 |101 years, 222 days |{{IND}} |- |11 |[[George Harman]] |align=center|Dublin University |6 June 1874 |14 December 1975 |101 years, 191 days |{{IRL}} |- |12 |[[Fred Gibson (cricketer)|Fred Gibson]] |align=center|Leicestershire |13 February 1912 |28 June 2013 |101 years, 135 days |{{JAM}} (lived in {{ENG}}) |- |13 |[[Alan Finlayson (cricketer)|Alan Finlayson]] |align=center|Eastern Province |1 September 1900 |28 October 2001 |101 years, 57 days |{{RSA}} |- |14 |[[Neil McCorkell]] |align=center|Hampshire, Players |23 March 1912 |28 February 2013 |100 years, 342 days |{{ENG}} |- |-bgcolor="99FF99" |15 |[[Archie Scott (cricketer)|Archie Scott]] |align=center|Scotland |26 January 1918 |Living | {{age in years and days|1918|01|26}} |Living in {{SCO}} |- |16 |[[Harold Stapleton]] |align=center|New South Wales |7 January 1915 |24 September 2015 | 100 years, 260 days |{{AUS}} |- |17 |[[Charles Braithwaite (cricketer)|Charles Braithwaite]] |align=center|English Residents, Players of USA |10 September 1845 |15 April 1946 |100 years, 217 days |{{USA}} |- |18 |[[Harry Forsyth]] |align=center|Dublin University |18 December 1903 |19 July 2004 |100 years, 214 days |{{IRL}} |- |19 |[[Jack Laver]] |align=center|Tasmania |9 March 1917 |3 October 2017 |100 years, 208 days |{{AUS}} |- |-bgcolor="99FF99" |20 |[[Geoffrey Beck (cricketer)|Geoffrey Beck]] |align=center|Oxford University |16 June 1918 |Living | {{age in years and days|1918|06|16}} |Living in {{ENG}} |- |21 |[[Tom Pritchard]] |align=center|Wellington, Warwickshire |10 March 1917 |22 August 2017 |100 years, 165 days |{{NZ}} |- |22 |[[George Deane]] |align=center|Hampshire |11 December 1828 |26 February 1929 |100 years, 77 days |{{ENG}} |} Note: Although born in New South Wales, Australia, Syd Ward and John Wheatley appear to have been raised in New Zealand. George Harman, who acquired two Rugby Union caps for Ireland, died in Cornwall. Charles Braithwaite was born in England. Fred Gibson moved to England in 1944. Neil McCorkell was born in England, but lived in South Africa from 1951. The prominent Antiguan cricketer, Sir [[Sydney Walling]], who died aged 102 years, 88 days in October 2009, never appeared in matches accorded first-class status. The oldest person, and only septuagenarian, to play [[first-class cricket|first-class]] cricket was [[Raja Maharaj Singh]], aged 72, his sole appearance being for the Bombay Governor's XI against a Commonwealth XI in November 1950.[http://content-www.cricinfo.com/india/content/story/304620.html Cricinfo: Ripe old age] ==Oldest women cricketers== England Women's cricketer [[Eileen Whelan]] (born 30 October 1911) was the first female Test cricketer to attain centenarian status, currently aged {{age in years and days|1911|10|30}}. [[Thelma McKenzie]] (Australia, born 6 April 1915) became second to achieve this landmark; she is currently aged {{age in years and days|1915|4|6}}. ==Oldest ODI cricketers== The oldest living ODI cricketer is [[Ray Illingworth]], currently aged {{age in years and days|1932|6|8}}. ==Oldest T20I cricketers== The oldest living T20I cricketer is [[Sanath Jayasuriya]], currently aged {{age in years and days|1969|6|30}}. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Lists of cricketers|Oldest]] [[Category:Test cricket records|Oldest]] [[Category:Lists of oldest people|Cricketers]]

{{Other uses|Mohammed Al Afghani (disambiguation){{!}}Mohammed Al Afghani}}
{{Infobox War on Terror detainee | name = Mohammed Al Afghani | image = Replace this image male.svg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth-date and age| }} --> | birth_place = | date_of_arrest = May 2004 | place_of_arrest = [[Peshawar|Peshawar, Pakistan]] | arresting_authority = Pakistani security officials | date_of_release = | place_of_release = | citizenship = [[Afghanistan]] | detained_at = | id_number = | group = | alias = | charge = | penalty = | status = Was held in [[extrajudicial detention]] in [[CIA]] custody, current location unknown | csrt_summary = | csrt_transcript = | occupation = | spouse = | parents = | children = }} '''Mohammed Al Afghani''' is a citizen of [[Afghanistan]], held by the [[United States]] in the [[CIA]]'s network of [[black sites]].<ref name=AmnestyInternationalOffTheRecord> {{cite news |url = https://www.amnesty.org.uk/uploads/documents/doc_17779.pdf |title = Off the Record: U.S. Responsibility for Enforced Disappearances in the "War on Terror" |date = |publisher = [[Amnesty International]] |accessdate = 2009-06-20 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110603032751/http://amnesty.org.uk/uploads/documents/doc_17779.pdf |archivedate = 2011-06-03 |df = }}</ref>
==Background== [[Amnesty International]] reports he was born in [[Saudi Arabia]]; that he was captured in [[Peshawar|Peshawar, Pakistan]], in May 2004;<ref name=AmnestyInternationalOffTheRecord/> that he was transferred from Pakistani custody on June 15, 2004, to CIA custody with three other men, including [[Marwan Jabour]].
==Disappearance== On April 22, 2009 ''[[Propublica]]'' published a list of CIA captives and its estimate of their current status.<ref name=Propublica2009-04-22> {{cite news | url=https://www.propublica.org/article/list-of-likely-cia-prisoners-who-are-still-missing-422 | title=List of Likely CIA Prisoners Who Are Still Missing | date=2009-04-22 | author=Dafna Lizner | publisher=[[Propublica]] <!-- | archivedate=2009-05-20 --> | accessdate=2009-05-20 }}</ref> The location and status of most of the individuals on that list were described simply as "unknown". They estimated that Mohammed Al Afghani had been transferred to the [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]]. The Department of Defense has acknowledged holding an individual they named as "[[Muhammad Rahim al Afghani]]"—but they said he was captured in [[Lahore]], Pakistan in 2007.<ref name=DoDIsn10030> {{cite news |url = http://www.defenselink.mil/releases/release.aspx?releaseid=11758 |title = Defense Department Takes Custody Of A High-Value Detainee |publisher = [[United States Department of Defense]] |author = |date = 2008-03-28 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.defenselink.mil%2Freleases%2Frelease.aspx%3Freleaseid%3D11758&date=2008-12-02 |archivedate = December 2, 2008 |accessdate = 2008-12-02 |quote = |deadurl = yes |df = }} </ref><ref name=WashingtonPost20080314> {{cite news | url=http://washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/03/14/AR2008031403702.html | title=U.S. Transfers Bin Laden Aide | page=A03 | publisher=[[Washington Post]] | author=[[Joby Warrick]] | date=15 March 2008 | accessdate=2008-03-15 | quote= }}</ref><ref name=NYTimes20080315> {{cite news | url=http://nytimes.com/2008/03/15/washington/15detain.html | title=C.I.A. Secretly Held Qaeda Suspect, Officials Say | publisher=[[New York Times]] | author=[[Mark Mazzetti]] | date=15 March 2008 | accessdate=2008-03-15 | quote=The Central Intelligence Agency secretly detained a suspected member of Al Qaeda for at least six months beginning last summer as part of a program in which C.I.A. officers have been authorized by President Bush to use harsh interrogation techniques, American officials said Friday. }}</ref><ref name=Dawn20080315> {{cite news | url=http://www.dawn.com/2008/03/15/top10.htm | title=US claims capturing Osama aide | publisher=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] | author= | date=15 March 2008 | accessdate=2008-03-15 | quote= }}</ref><ref name=Abc20080314> {{cite news | url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=4453407&page=1 | title=CIA: We Got Bin Laden Translator | publisher=[[ABC News]] | author=[[Jonathon Karl]] | date=14 March 2008 | accessdate=2008-03-15 | quote= }}</ref><ref name=DoDAfps20080314> {{cite news | url=http://www.defenselink.mil/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=49283 | title=Defense Department Takes Custody of High-Value Al Qaeda Operative | publisher=[[American Forces Press Service]] | author=[[Jim Garamone]] | date=14 March 2008 | accessdate=2008-03-15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809024956/http://www.defenselink.mil/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=49283 |archivedate=August 9, 2009 | quote= }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Other uses|Patricia Sullivan (disambiguation){{!}}Patricia Sullivan}} '''Patricia Sullivan''' is an [[United States|American]], a resident of [[Florida]], who became a leader in the modern [[Tea Party movement]].<ref> {{cite news | url = http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/state/florida-legislature-to-open-with-unhappy-activists-on-2091688.html | title = Florida Legislature to open with unhappy activists on left and right | publisher = [[Palm Beach Host]] | date = 2012-01-09 | accessdate = 2012-01-15 | quote = The Tea Party Network, a coalition of about 80 groups, set up shop in a second-floor conference room in the Senate during committee weeks this fall. Tuesday, they'll host a coffee -- Lt. Gov. Jennifer Carroll is slated to attend -- and have an appearance by conservative activist and syndicated columnist Star Parker, said Tea Party Network Chairwoman Patricia Sullivan. | author = Dara Kam }} </ref>
Sullivan ran for the [[United States House of Representatives]] under the Tea Party banner in 2010.<ref name=OrlandoSentinel> {{cite news | url = http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-12-06/news/os-house-redistricting-maps-20111206_1_senate-maps-senate-district-maps-legislative-maps | title = House redistricting maps would add Hispanic seats | publisher = [[Orlando Sentinel]] | date = 2011-12-06 | accessdate = 2011-01-15 | quote = "Compared to the districts we have now, it's clear you have followed what we asked for," said Patricia Sullivan of Eustis, who ran for Congress under the tea party banner last year. She did note, though, that Lake County appeared to get "the short end of the stick" because it was divided between several Senate and congressional seats. | page = | author = }} </ref> The ''[[Orlando Sentinel]]'' quoted her opinion over proposed [[Congressional redistricting]].
In February 2011, [[Florida Governor]] [[Rick Scott]] traveled to Sullivan's hometown of [[Eustis, Florida]] to release the state's 2011 budget.<ref> {{cite news | url = http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2011-02-06/news/fl-tea-party-influence-box-20110206_1_tea-partiers-rick-scott-north-lake-tea-party | title = Why Eustis? It's the 'soul of Florida' | publisher = [[Sun Sentinel]] | date = 2011-02-06 | accessdate = 2012-01-15 | quote = Patricia Sullivan, co-founder of the North Lake Tea Party and a stay-at-home mom, is credited with scoring this political coup. Scott's office called tea party groups around Florida weeks ago looking for a spot to unveil the budget. }} </ref> Scott's office sought out Tea Party leaders for suggestions for where he should release the budget. The ''Orlando Sentinel'' described his choice of Sullivan's town as a political coup on her part. Scott's decision was described by the chair of the [[Lake County, Florida|Lake County]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] as an attempt "to get an army together to back his tax cuts."<ref> {{cite news | url = http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-02-06/business/os-rick-scott-tea-party-20110206_1_tea-party-movement-tax-cuts-spending-cuts | title = Rick Scott to present budget proposal not at Capitol, but at Tea Party rally in Eustis on Monday | publisher = [[Orlando Sentinel]] | date = 2011-02-06 | accessdate = 2012-01-15 | quote = ‘I have no doubt he is trying to get an army together to back his tax cuts’, said Lake County Democratic Party Chair Nancy Hurlbert. | page = | author = Scott Powers, Martin E. Comas }} </ref> 7,000 people came to Eustis for the budget.
On November 30, 2011, when the resignation of [[Herman Cain]], a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Presidential contender, seemed imminent, the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' sought Sullivan's opinion as to who would replace him as a lead contender.<ref name=BostonGlobe2011-11-30> {{cite news | url = http://articles.boston.com/2011-11-30/news/30459374_1_mitt-romney-cain-backers-sexual-harassment-accusations | title = Cain reconsidering campaign after allegation of 13-year affair: Departure could hurt Romney bid, polling suggests | publisher = [[Boston Globe]] | date = 2011-11-30 | accessdate = 2012-01-15 | quote = Patricia Sullivan, a Tea Party leader from Florida, said she does not know whom she would support if Cain were to drop out. But she knows which candidate definitely will not get her vote: Romney. "Absolutely not", said Sullivan, who is chairwoman of The Tea Party Network, a coalition of 79 Tea Party groups in Florida. "Romney is like the antithesis of Cain. Romney is a champion for Romney. Cain is a champion for the people." Sullivan said she likes Gingrich’s combative style in debates, but does not view him as an alternative to Cain. She said she is concerned that he may not be as conservative as some believe. | page = | author = Michael Levenson }} </ref> She didn't state who she would support as an alternative to Cain, but she offered criticism of [[Mitt Romney]].
Six days later, following the Cain's resignation, Marc Caputo, of the ''[[Miami Herald]]'' sought Sullivan's opinion as a key member of Cain's support team.<ref name=TampaBayTimes2011-12-06> {{cite news | url = http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/national/herman-cain-supporters-where-do-they-go-now/1204959 | title = Herman Cain supporters: Where do they go now? | publisher = [[Tampa Bay Times]] | date = 2011-12-06 | accessdate = 2012-01-15 | quote = Patricia Sullivan, a Lake County tea party organizer who was part of Cain's campaign, said the candidate left a legacy that spoke to the power of the grass roots. "What I'm doing is I'm taking a step back and I'm reassessing what I want from a candidate," she said. "Because what I wanted I can't have. I wanted a champion for the people." When asked who was definitely off her list, Sullivan listed Romney, Paul, Jon Huntsman and Michele Bachmann. That leaves Texas Gov. Rick Perry, former Pennsylvania Sen. Rick Santorum and former House Speaker Gingrich. | page = | author = Marc Caputo }} </ref> At that time she ruled out Mitt Romney, [[Ron Paul]], [[Jon Huntsman, Jr.|Jon Huntsman]] and [[Michele Bachmann]]. Sullivan came second to [[Blaise Ingoglia]] in the [[Florida Republican Party]]'s choice of chairman.<ref> {{cite news |url = http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/blog/blaise-ingoglia-tops-tea-partier-patricia-sullivan-keep-rpof-vice-chair |title = Blaise Ingoglia Tops Tea Partier Patricia Sullivan to Keep RPOF Vice Chair; National Committeeman Elected |publisher = [[Sunshine State News]] |date = 2012-01-15 |accessdate = 2012-01-15 |quote = Sullivan, who chairs the Tea Party Network, a statewide coalition of 80 tea and patriot groups, entered the contest just 48 hours before the vote. She was nominated by state Sen. Alan Hays, R-Umatilla. A Lake County resident who ran for Congress in 2010, Sullivan said, "My role in the [RPOF] election was to provide people with a choice." "We voted on a resolution, welcoming tea party members into our Republican Executive Committees. Now let's walk the walk and unite our voices," she told the GOP gathering. |page = |author = Kenric Ward |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130203091418/http://www.sunshinestatenews.com/blog/blaise-ingoglia-tops-tea-partier-patricia-sullivan-keep-rpof-vice-chair |archivedate = 2013-02-03 |df = }} </ref>

{{short description|Nepalese mountain climber and trekking leader}} '''Pertemba''' (born 15 February 1948), also called '''Pertemba Sherpa''', is a professional [[Nepal]]ese mountaineer, trek leader and businessman. He reached the summit of [[1975 British Mount Everest Southwest Face expedition|Mount Everest by the Southwest Face]] on the first expedition to successfully take that route, in 1975. ==Biography== Pertemba was born in 1948 in [[Khumjung]], [[Solukhumbu District|Solukhumbu]] where his father farmed with about forty yaks. He was sent to live with his grandpapents near [[Cho Oyo]] in the [[Gokyo]] valley when he was five and then his aunts living near [[Tengboche Monastery]] looked after him. He studied with the monks there but when he was eight he became very ill and almost died.{{cite book|author1=Pertemba Sherpa|editor1-last=Bonington|editor1-first=Chris|editor2-last=Salkeld|editor2-first=Audrey|title=Great Climbs|date=1994|publisher=Mitchell Beazley|isbn=1-85732-573-7 |pages=192-197|chapter=The Sherpa View}} He started his education in 1961 at a school founded by [[Edmund Hillary]] was first opened and where he stayed for five years.{{cite web|title=Board of Himalayan Trust Nepal, Pertemba Sherpa, Vice Chairman|url=http://www.himalayantrust.co.nz/board-of-himalayan-trust-nepal/|publisher=[[Himalayan Trust]]|accessdate=31 August 2014}}
{{cite news|last1=Reaney|first1=Patricia|title=Life for Nepal's Sherpas Hit Peak With Hillary's Arrival, Guide Says|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-07-09/news/mn-5238_1_sherpa-people|accessdate=31 August 2014|work=Los Angeles times|date=9 July 1989}}
{{cite web|last1=Bonington|first1=Chris|title=Sir Chris Bonington|url=http://www.geographical.co.uk/Magazine/People/Sir_Chris_Bonington_Nov07.html|publisher=Geographical|accessdate=31 August 2014|date=November 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616064341/http://www.geographical.co.uk/Magazine/People/Sir_Chris_Bonington_Nov07.html|archivedate=16 June 2013|df=}} Failing to get a scholarship to continue his education, in 1966 he got a job in the kitchen at [[Lukla Airport]] and then, helped by his knowledge of English, he moved to [[Kathmandu]] to join the first trekking agency in [[Nepal]], Jimmy Roberts' Mountain Travel. He first was a high-altitude porter on a number of expeditions before he became a [[Sherpa people|Sherpa]] leader or [[Sardar|sirdar]].{{cite web|last1=Sacred Summits|title=Mr. Pertemba Sherpa|url=http://www.sherpaheritagehouse.org/pertemba-sherpa.pdf|website=Sherpa Heritage House|publisher=Sherpa Heritage House|accessdate=31 August 2014}} He has donated his family's ancestral house in Khumjung for it to become the Sherpa Heritage House museum – it is the last traditional house in Solu Khhumbu.{{cite web|title=The Sherpa Heritage House|url=http://www.sherpaheritagehouse.org/|publisher=Sherpa Heritage Home|accessdate=1 September 2014}} Pertemba is vice chairman of the [[Himalayan Trust]] and was a founder member of the Kathmandu Environmental Education Project. He has been an executive member of the Himalayan Rescue Association, and of the [[Nepal Mountaineering Association]]. He has been awarded the [[Order of Gorkha Dakshina Bahu]] (first class) by the [[Birendra of Nepal|King of Nepal]]. Bonington has described him as being assured and dynamic.{{cite book|last1=Bonington|first1=Chris|title=Everest the Hard Way|date=1976|publisher=Hodder and Stoughton|location=London|isbn=0340208333|page=62}} Pertemba is married and has children. ==Mountaineering and trekking== He took part as a climber in [[Chris Bonington]]'s 1970 [[Annapurna]] and 1975 Everest Southwest Face expeditions (the latter as sirdar). Bonington said he consulted Pertemba frequently, sometimes to the irritation of the lead climbers when he accepted the sirdar's opinion over theirs of the capabilities of the Sherpas and even on the best route to be followed.{{cite book|last1=Bonington|first1=Chris|title=Everest the Hard Way|date=1976|publisher=Hodder and Stoughton|location=London|isbn=0340208333|page=73}} He was expedition co-leader on the American first ascent of [[Gauri Sankar]] in 1979.{{cite book|last1=Fisher|first1=James F.|title=Sherpas: Reflections on Change in Himalayan Nepal|date=1990|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520909946|page=98|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0LjDjCcempQC&pg=PA98|accessdate=31 August 2014}} He has climbed [[Mount Everest]] three times although he stopped climbing in 1995 while continuing to lead climbing and trekking expeditions.{{cite web|title=Congratulations !!! EcoEverest Expedition Spring 2012|url=http://www.asian-trekking.com/blog/item/275-congratulations-eco-everest-expedition-spring-2012.html?tmpl=component&print=1|website=Asian Trekking|accessdate=31 August 2014}} In 1985 with two business partners he established a trekking agency called Nepal Himal and he has given climbing seminars in the United States and Europe. Pertemba has also climbed in Switzerland, Alaska and Britain.{{cite web|last1=Horrell|first1=Mark|title=10 great Sherpa mountaineers|url=http://www.markhorrell.com/blog/2014/10-great-sherpa-mountaineers/|website=Footsteps on the Mountain|accessdate=31 August 2014}} ==See also== *[[List of Mount Everest summiters by number of times to the summit]] *[[List of 20th-century summiters of Mount Everest]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pertemna Sherpa}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Solukhumbu District]] [[Category:Nepalese people]] [[Category:Nepalese mountain climbers]] [[Category:Nepalese summiters of Mount Everest]] [[Category:Sherpa summiters of Mount Everest]] [[Category:Members of the Order of Gorkha Dakshina Bahu, First Class]]

[[File:Asolocup.PNG|thumb|200px|right|Hulseman's well known invention, the red solo cup.]] '''Robert Leo "Bob" Hulseman''' (April 5, 1932 – December 21, 2016) was an American [[businessman]] and [[entrepreneur]] who was best known as the [[inventor]] of the [[Solo Cup Company|red solo cup]], which is produced by his family's company, [[Solo Cup Company]]. He also co-designed the Traveler Lid, which prevents foam from [[List of hot drinks|hot beverages]] such as [[lattes]] and [[cappuccinos]] from touching the drinker's nose, now widely used by [[Starbucks]] and other brands.<ref name=syracuse>{{cite news|first=Geoff|last=Herbert |title=Red Solo Cup creator Robert Leo Hulseman dies at 84 |url=http://www.syracuse.com/us-news/index.ssf/2016/12/red_solo_cup_creator_robert_leo_hulseman_dead.html |work=[[The Post-Standard]] |publisher= |date=2016-12-29 |accessdate=2017-01-20}}</ref><ref name=ctribune>{{cite news|first=Ally|last=Marotti |title=Robert L. Hulseman, Chicago-area creator of famed red Solo Cup, dies at 84 |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-hulseman-solo-cup-inventor-dies-1230-biz-20161229-story.html |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |publisher= |date=2016-12-29 |accessdate=2017-01-20}}</ref><ref name=nytimes>{{cite news|first=Richard |last=Sandomir |title=Robert L. Hulseman, Inventor of the Solo Cup, Dies at 84 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/30/business/robert-hulseman-dead-red-solo-cup.html |work=[[New York Times]] |publisher= |date=2016-12-30 |accessdate=2017-01-20}}</ref> Hulseman joined the staff of The Solo Cup Company, which had been founded in 1936 by his father Leo Hulseman, when he was 18 years old.<ref name=syracuse/> Hulseman spent more than 60 years at the Solo Cup Company, including as the company's President and [[CEO]] from 1980 until 2006.<ref name=syracuse/>
Hulseman developed and introduced the red solo cup, which crucial product of the Solo Cup Company and a part of everyday life for many Americans.<ref name=ctribune/> The cup became an icon of college and [[Tailgate party|tailgate parties]] and an essential element in popular [[drinking games]], including [[beer pong]].<ref name=syracuse/> The red cup was further popularized by [[Toby Keith]]'s 2011 hit single, "[[Red Solo Cup]]".<ref name=syracuse/><ref name=nytimes/>
==Biography== ===Early and personal life=== Hulseman was born in [[Chicago, Illinois]], on April 5, 1932.<ref name=nytimes/> His mother, Dorothy (née Hall), was a singer known by the stage name Dora Hall, while his father, Leo Hulseman, established the Solo Cup Company, a manufacturer of disposable cups, bowls and plates, in 1936.<ref name=nytimes/> Robert Hulseman survived polio as a teenager, which left one of his legs shorter than the other, which was surgically corrected, and affected the left side of his body.<ref name=nytimes/>
He met his wife, Sheila, with whom he had ten children, while both were students at [[Marquette University]].<ref name=ctribune/> He also briefly served in the United States Army.<ref name=nytimes/>
===Career=== His father, Leo Hulseman, a former [[Dixie Cup]] employee, had founded the Solo Cup Company in 1936.<ref name=syracuse/><ref name=nytimes/> Robert Hulseman joined his father's company as a factory worker when he was 18-years old and worked his way through a series of jobs.<ref name=nytimes/> Hulseman later developed the Solo Cup Company's plastic business, which would lead to the development of the plastic red solo cup during the 1970s.<ref name=nytimes/>
Robert Hulseman created the solo cup during the mid-1970s and utilized his own children and family as a [[focus group]].<ref name=ctribune/> Hulseman would place small plastic cups of varying colors on his kitchen table for his kids to peruse, including blue, red, peach and yellow.<ref name=ctribune/> While the peach cups were not a hit, the red solo cups proved popular with both his children and consumers.<ref name=ctribune/> Hulseman, himself, favored blue solo cups.<ref name=nytimes/>
Husleman initially launched the red solo cups in smaller 5, 7 and 9 ounce sizes.<ref name=ctribune/> However, he eventually introduced the iconic 16 ounce red solo cup, which proved to be the most popular size long term.<ref name=ctribune/> When the 16 ounce red cups were first sold, very few consumers drank beers that size. However, consumer tastes changed to match the size of the popular plastic cups.<ref name=ctribune/> Today, the plastic solo cups are manufactured in dozens of colors, but the red solo cups remain the company's best seller.<ref name=nytimes/>
Hulseman became President of the Solo Cup Company, which he inherited from his father, in 1980, succeeding his father.<ref name=nytimes/> He later became the company's CEO as well.<ref name=nytimes/>
In 1986, Hulseman and his employee, Jack Clements, developed the Traveler Lid for use on coffee cups and other hot beverage containers.<ref name=nytimes/> The Traveler Lid provides space for foam or whipped cream for hot drinks, such as cappuccinos and lattes, and prevents the foam from reaching the consumer's nose.<ref name=syracuse/><ref name=nytimes/> While both Clements and Hulseman designed the lid, Clements retains the rights to its [[patent]].<ref name=nytimes/> The [[Museum of Modern Art]] (MoMA) in [[New York City]] honored the Traveler Lid as part of its 122 "Humble Masterpieces" of design exhibition in 2004.<ref name=nytimes/>
He retired as CEO in 2006, two years after the family company had acquired rival [[Sweetheart Cup Company]], another manufacturer of [[disposable cup]]s.<ref name=syracuse/><ref name=nytimes/>
Hulseman was also a devote [[Catholic]] and a [[philanthropist]], known to support [[anti-poverty]] initiatives and [[Catholic schools]].<ref name=syracuse/> He and his family attended Mass weekly at Saints Faith, Hope and Charity Roman Catholic Church in [[Winnetka, Illinois]].<ref name=ctribune/>
The Solo Cup Company was acquired by the [[Dart Container|Dart Container Corporation]] in 2012.<ref name=ctribune/>
Hulseman's health deteriorated during his later years following a series of strokes.<ref name=ctribune/> He died from stroke complications at his home in [[Northfield, Illinois]], on December 21, 2016, at the age of 84.<ref name=ctribune/><ref name=nytimes/> He was survived by nine children and 30 grandchildren.<ref name=syracuse/> His wife, Sheila, whom he had been married to for 60 years, died in August 2015 and one of his children, Jean Hulseman Kloos, died in August 2016.<ref name=syracuse/>
Country singer Toby Keith paid tribute to Hulseman on [[Twitter]], writing, "Raise one for this good man today."<ref name=nytimes/>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Roger Corless | image = Roger.corless.at.coyote.state.park.jpg | caption = At Coyote State Park | title = Professor of Religion
[[Duke University]] | residence = [[United States]] | birth_date = June 26, 1938 | birth_place = [[Merseyside]], England | death_date = January 12, 2007 | death_place = San Francisco, California | nationality = British | citizenship = American | education = Ph.D. (Buddhist Studies), [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]], 1973 | website = http://www.thecorless.com }} '''Roger Corless''' (1938–2007) made significant contributions to [[interfaith dialogue]], particularly on the subject Buddhist-Christian [[Dual Belonging|dual belonging]] ("co-inherent consciousness").See the article below, "On Becoming a Dialogian." He was Professor of Religion at [[Duke University]], and held visiting positions at the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], [[Stanford University]], [[Chaminade University of Honolulu]], [[California Institute of Integral Studies]], [[University of California-Berkeley]], and the [[Institute of Buddhist Studies]]. ==Biographical brief== Roger Corless studied at [[King's College London]] (B.D., 1961) and the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] (Ph.D., Buddhist Studies, 1973). His special interests were [[Pure Land Buddhism]], [[Catholic Spirituality|Christian Spirituality]], and Buddhist-Christian Dialogue. He was a co-founder of the Society for Buddhist-Christian Studies and its journal ''[[Buddhist-Christian Studies]]'' ([[University of Hawaii]] Press). He published four books, including ''[[The Vision of Buddhism]]'', and more than sixty scholarly articles. ==Selected bibliography== ;Books *''The Art of Christian Alchemy: Transfiguring the Ordinary through Holistic Meditation''. Paulist Press, 1981. *''I am Food: The Mass in Planetary Perspective''. Wipf and Stock, 2004. Originally published by Crossroad, 1981. *''[[The Vision of Buddhism (book)|The Vision of Buddhism: The Space under the Tree]]''. Paragon House, 1989. *''Buddhist Emptiness and Christian Trinity: Essays and Explorations''. ed. with [[Paul F. Knitter]]. Paulist Press, 1990. (Contains his article “Can Emptiness Will?”) *''Where do we Go from Here? The Many Religions and the Next Step''. Draft completed, publisher being sought. ;Articles *“An Essay on the Place of the Text in Buddhist and Christian Formation.” ''Studies in Formative Spirituality'' XIV:1 (February 1993), 31–40. *“The Coming of the Dialogian: A Transpersonal Approach to Interreligious Dialogue.” ''Dialogue and Alliance: A Journal of the International Religious Foundation'' 7:2 (Fall/Winter 1993), 3–17. *“A Form for Buddhist-Christian Co-Inherence Meditation” and “A Reply to the Responses”. ''Buddhist-Christian Studies'' 14 (1994), 139–144 and 181–184 (part of the forum on Joint Practice, pages 137–196). *“A Buddhist Understanding of HIV/AIDS.” ''Religion in the Age of AIDS: Strategy and Theology from the AIDS & Religion in America Convention'' (San Francisco: Public Media Center; Washington DC: AIDS National Interfaith Network, 1999), pages 59–63. *“Towards a Queer Dharmology of Sex.” ''Culture and Religion'' 5:2 (July 2004), 229–243. ==Notes== ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.thecorless.com/media/roger/corless.becoming.a.dialogian.text.pdf "On Becoming a Dialogian"] An essay by Roger Corless. * [http://www.thecorless.com The Corless] A nonprofit formed out of Roger Corless's estate. Many of Roger's papers, some unpublished, are in their archives. * [http://www.innerexplorations.com/catew/9.htm Profiles in Buddhist-Christian Dialogue] An interview with Roger Corless. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Corless, Roger}} [[Category:Buddhist philosophers]] [[Category:Queer theologians]] [[Category:20th-century theologians]] [[Category:Religion academics]] [[Category:Alumni of King's College London]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]]

'''Samson "Sam" Uriah Morris''' (1908–June 1976) was a [[Grenada]]-born educationalist, anti-colonialist and [[civil rights]] activist who came to [[London]] in 1939, becoming deputy chair for the [[Commission for Racial Equality]] in the 1970s.<ref>Petra Pryke, "YT? Youth Training in the visual arts: The Sam Morris Project", in Patricia Potts, Felicity Armstrong and Mary Masterton (eds), ''Equality and Diversity in Education vol. 1, Learning, Teaching and Managing in Schools''. Routledge, 1995, p. 153.</ref>
== Biography == Morris was born in St Andrew's, [[Grenada]], in 1908 and received part of his education in [[Barbados]] at [[Codrington College]]. In 1939, he sailed to the [[United Kingdom]], and served in the British Army for two and a half years. He subsequently became active in the [[League of Coloured Peoples]] — which was formed by [[Harold Moody (physician)|Harold Moody]] and was concerned with racial equality and civil rights in Britain and elsewhere in the world — becoming general secretary of the organisation in 1945. Morris participated in several BBC programmes, including ''Calling the West Indies'' and ''[[Caribbean Voices]]''.
He was a Liaison Officer to [[Learie Constantine]] in the Welfare Department of the [[Colonial Office]] during the [[Second World War]]. In 1953 Morris left Britain for Africa and worked on Radio Ghana before becoming a private secretary and press officer to [[Kwame Nkrumah]] in Ghana for eight years, returning to the UK in 1967. He was then the Development Officer for the Midlands with the National Committee for Commonwealth Immigrants.<ref>Pendennis. "Who's Who in Race", ''[[The Observer]]'', London, 3 March 1968.</ref> He later became Assistant High Commissioner for Grenada and deputy chair for the [[Commission for Racial Equality]]. He lived in [[Hammersmith]] and was an active member of the Hammersmith and Fulham Council for Racial Equality. He died in June 1976 in [[Fulham]], London.
== Selected writings ==
*"My Tribute to the Late George Padmore", ''Accra Evening News'', 3 October 1959. *"Tribute to Learie Constantine", ''New Community'', 1, 1 (October 1971), pp. 68–70. *"Moody — the forgotten visionary", ''New Community'' (Vol. 1, No. 3, Spring 1972), pp. 193–96. *''The Case and the Course: A Treatise on Black Studies'' (London: Committee on Black Studies 1973).
== Legacy == There is a Sam Uriah Morris Society that had a centre in East London with an exhibition about black history.<ref>[http://apps.hackney.gov.uk/servapps/hackneydirectory/details.aspx?OrgID=6299 ''Sam Uriah Morris Society'']. Hackney Council website. Accessed 31 March 2014.</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * Hannah Ishmael, 'Samson Uriah Morris', ''Dictionary of Caribbean and Afro–Latin American Biography'' (2016). * Roderick J. Macdonald, "Dr. Harold Arundel Moody and the League of Coloured Peoples, 1931-1947: A Retrospective View", ''Race & Class'' 14/3 (January 1973). * Petra Pryke, "YT? Youth Training in the visual arts: The Sam Morris Project", in Patricia Potts, Felicity Armstrong and Mary Masterton (eds), ''Equality and Diversity in Education vol. 1, Learning, Teaching and Managing in Schools'' (Routledge, 1995), p. 153. * [http://www.samuriahmorrissociety.org.uk ''Sam Uriah Morris Society''.] {{Authority control}}

{{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Other people|Sue Black}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Sue Black | honorific_suffix = {{Post-nominals|OBE|FBCS|FRSA|size=100%|country = GBR}} | image = Dr Sue Black visiting Brazil.jpg | caption = Sue Black in 2012 | birth_name = Susan Elizabeth Black | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1962}} | birth_place = [[Fareham]], Hampshire, England | thesis_title = Computation of Ripple Effect Measures for Software | thesis_year = 2001 | thesis_url = | nationality = British | alma_mater = [[London South Bank University]] (PhD) | fields = {{Plainlist| * Software engineering * [[Social media]] * [[Women in STEM fields|Women in tech]] * [[Bletchley Park]] * Twitter}} | workplaces = [[University College London]]
[[University of Westminster]] | awards = {{Plainlist| * John Ivinson Award {{small|(2009)}} * [[Order of the British Empire]] {{small|(2016)}}}} | module = {{Listen | filename = Sue Black voice.oga | title = Sue Black's voice | type = speech | embed = yes | description = recorded February 2013 }} | website = {{URL|sueblack.co.uk}} }} '''Susan Elizabeth Black''' {{Post-nominals|size=100%|OBE|FBCS|FRSA|country = GBR}} (born 1962) is a British [[computer scientist]], academic and [[social entrepreneur]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sueblack.co.uk|title= Dr Sue Black official webpage|publisher=sueblack.co.uk}}{{DBLP|name=Sue Black}}{{Google scholar id}} She has been instrumental in saving [[Bletchley Park]], the site of [[World War II]] [[codebreaking]], with her ''Saving Bletchley Park'' campaign.{{cite web|url=http://www.savingbletchleypark.org |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081109070803/http://savingbletchleypark.org/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-11-09 |publisher=savingbletchleypark.org |title=Saving Bletchley Park }}{{YouTube|id=fKQYECYJEH0|title=Interview with Sue Black by Robert Llewellyn about Bletchley Park}} ==Early life and education== Sue Black was born in 1962 in [[Fareham]], Hampshire.{{cite web|url=http://runnethlondon.com/2017/02/16/inspiring-woman-dr-sue-black-obe/|title=Inspiring Woman: Dr Sue Black, OBE|date=16 February 2017|publisher=runnethlondon.com|accessdate=28 October 2017}} She left school and home at the earliest legal age, 16. She married at 20 and soon had three children.{{cite web|last1=Black|first1=Sue|title=Bio + Contact|url=https://blackse.wordpress.com/contact/|website=blackse|accessdate=21 May 2016|quote=Dr Sue Black left home and school at 16, married at 20 and had 3 children by the age of 23. A single parent at 25 she went to university, gained a degree in computing then a PhD in software engineering.}} By 25, she was a [[single mother]] living in a [[women's refuge]]. She took a maths [[access course]] at night school that led to enrolling in undergraduate degree.{{cite news|last1=Fleming|first1=Amy|title=#techmums: why can't geeks be mothers too?| url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2013/nov/11/techmums-geeks-mothers-technology | accessdate=21 May 2016 | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | date=11 November 2013 }} Black graduated with a bachelor's degree in [[computing]] from [[London South Bank University]]{{cite web| url=http://www.lsbu.ac.uk/about-us/news/sue-black-becomes-obe | title=LSBU alumna Sue Black becomes an OBE in New Year Honours List 2016 | date=5 January 2016 | publisher=[[London South Bank University]] | location=UK | accessdate=7 January 2016 }} in 1993, and earned her PhD in software engineering{{cite thesis |degree=PhD |first=Susan Elizabeth|last=Black |title=Computation of Ripple Effect Measures for Software |website=wmin.ac.uk |publisher=London Southbank University |year=2001 |url=http://users.wmin.ac.uk/sueblackthesis2001.zip }} {{dead|date=May 2017}} in 2001Sue Black {{ORCID|0000-0002-9315-9517}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sueblack.co.uk/publications.html|publisher=sueblack.co.uk|title=Publications by Dr Sue Black|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411130838/http://www.sueblack.co.uk/publications.html|archivedate=11 April 2009|df=dmy-all}}{{MathGenealogy|id=103014|title=Susan Elizabeth Black}} for research on the [[ripple effect]].{{cite journal|last1=Black|first1=Sue|title=Computing ripple effect for software maintenance|journal=Journal of Software Maintenance and Evolution: Research and Practice|volume=13|issue=4|year=2001|pages=263–279|issn=1532060X|doi=10.1002/smr.233}} ==Career and research== Black is a Senior Research Associate at [[University College London]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.ucl.ac.uk/people/S.Black.html |title=Sue Black profile |publisher=[[University College London]] |location=UK |accessdate=7 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303202754/http://www0.cs.ucl.ac.uk/people/S.Black.html |archivedate= 3 March 2016 |df= }} She was previously Head of the Department of Information and Software Systems at the [[University of Westminster]]. Black was the founding chair of the BCS Specialist Group [[BCSWomen]][http://www.bcs.org/server.php?show=ConWebDoc.8353 Dr Sue Black|Committee|BCSWomen], [[British Computer Society]]. and remained in that position until 2008. She is an advocate of [[women in computing]].[http://skirtsandladders.com/?tag=sue-black Sue Black profile],[http://skirtsandladders.com/ Skirts and Ladders]. ===Campaigns=== Black ran a successful campaign over several years to secure funding for the restoration of [[Bletchley Park]], the UK [[World War II]] centre for decrypting enemy messages.Cellan-Jones, Rory, ''[http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/technology/2009/03/bletchley_parks_social_media_w.html Bletchley Park's social media war]'', [[BBC News]], 18 March 2009. In 2003, she started raising awareness of the site by creating a blog,Brain, Jon, ''[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7523743.stm Neglect of Bletchley condemned]'', [[BBC News]], 24 July 2008. after visiting the site and noting the appalling condition of the buildings, seeing the Bombe machine being rebuilt, and hearing that over 10,000 people had worked there during the war. The photograph of one of the huts with a blue tarpaulin protecting the deteriorating structure helped galvanise interest and activism among concerned computer scientists. The initial outreach was followed up with an active Twitter presence that attracted even more followers and interested parties. Bletchley Park staff also engaged with other [[Web 2.0]] (i.e. user-generated) technologies such as Facebook and Twitter.{{cite news| last=Thomson | first=Rebecca | url=http://www.computerweekly.com/Articles/2009/03/19/235325/bletchley-park-wins-crucial-funding-using-facebook-and.htm | title=Bletchley Park wins crucial funding using Facebook and Twitter | newspaper=[[Computer Weekly]] | date=19 March 2009 }}{{Cite news |url=http://www.archimuse.com/mw2010/papers/black/black.html |title=Can Twitter Save Bletchley Park? |last=Black |first=Sue |date=13–17 April 2010 |work=Museums and the Web 2010 |publisher=[[Archives & Museum Informatics]] |last2=Bowen |first2=Jonathan P. |editor-last=Bearman |editor-first=David |location=[[Denver]], United States |last3=Griffin |first3=Kelsey |editor2-first=Jennifer |editor2-last=Trant}} At the end of 2015, Black published a book about the process, ''Saving Bletchley Park'', initially funded via [[Unbound (publisher)|Unbound]],{{Cite web|title = Saving Bletchley Park|url = https://unbound.co.uk/books/saving-bletchley-park|website = Unbound|accessdate = 30 December 2015}} that became the fastest [[Crowdfunding|crowdfunded]] book of all time.{{Cite web|url=http://www.womanthology.co.uk/celebrating-the-incredible-codebreakers-of-bletchley-park-dr-sue-black-computer-scientist-writer-and-speaker/|title=Celebrating the incredible codebreakers of Bletchley Park – Dr. Sue Black OBE, Computer Scientist, Writer and Speaker – Womanthology|website=Womanthology|access-date=7 April 2016}} [[everywoman]] says Black "embodies the traits of a modern leader", particularly in regard to social media use.{{cite web|title=#techmums Founder Dr Sue Black's rules for elevating your personal social media presence |url=https://www.everywoman.com/personal-development/personal-branding/techmums-founder-dr-sue-blacks-rules-elevating-your-personal |website=Everywoman |accessdate=21 May 2016 |quote=Dr Sue Black, Founder of Savvify #techmums – empowering mums to get excited about technology – and winner of the Inspiration of the Year award at the FDM everywoman in Technology Awards in March 2014, embodies the traits of the modern leader – engaged with her audience, transparent, open and authentic |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611102646/https://www.everywoman.com/personal-development/personal-branding/techmums-founder-dr-sue-blacks-rules-elevating-your-personal |archivedate=11 June 2016 |df= }} The BBC technology correspondent [[Rory Cellan-Jones]] spotted early on that Black was making sophisticated use of Twitter (and other platforms) in her campaigning.{{cite web| last=Cellan-Jones | first=Rory | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/technology/2009/03/bletchley_parks_social_media_w.html | website=dot.life A blog about technology from [[BBC News]] | publisher=[[BBC]] | accessdate=21 May 2016 | date=18 March 2009 | title=Bletchley Park's social media war | quote=A vital component in this campaign has been what you might call the propaganda war – although one which has employed the most modern of weapons. Dr Black has assembled a significant crowd of supporters for Bletchley Park – geeks, history buffs, technologically literate celebrities – using all the modern social media tools.}}{{cite web|last1=Cellan-Jones|first1=Rory|title=OBE for Bletchley campaigner Sue Black|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-35202667|website=BBC News Technology|publisher=BBC|accessdate=21 May 2016|date=30 December 2015|quote=Others had been battling for years to make the same case without much success, but in 2008 social media was just beginning to play an important role in campaigning, and Dr Black made full use of it.}} Black set up ''Techmums'', reaching out to mothers who wanted to understand what their children were up to online. Techmums offers free training in digital security, social media, the programming language [[Python (programming language)|Python]], and so on, with the aim of increasing the women's confidence, breaking down the [[digital divide]], and helping them escape poverty. The pilot programme was held at [[Bishop Challoner Catholic Collegiate School]] in [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]]. Techmums describes itself as "an e-skills accredited program of short, hands-on workshops" with a supportive online community.{{cite web|website=techmums.co|title=About|url=http://techmums.co/about/|accessdate=21 May 2016|quote=What is #techmums? #techmums is an e-skills accredited program of short, hands-on workshops that introduce mums to online security, social media savviness, essential computing skills, app and web design. In addition there is opportunity for mums to be introduced to simple Python programming to gain understanding of the computer skills their children may learn at school. #techmums programs are delivered via schools either directly by a #techmums trainer or by the school themselves. All mums enrolled onto the program are further supported by a dedicated #techmums online community.}} Dr Black has appeared on [[BBC]] television, radio and in press articles.{{cite web | url=http://www.sueblack.co.uk/press.html | title=Dr Sue Black: Press | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411121257/http://www.sueblack.co.uk/press.html | archivedate=11 April 2009 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite news| last=Smyth | first=Chris | url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article4387286.ece | title=Scientists send clear message: save Bletchley Park | newspaper=[[The Times]] | date=24 July 2008 }}{{cite news| last=Arthur | first=Charles, | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2009/sep/29/bletchley-park-lottery-grant | title=Bletchley Park's codebreakers get glimpse of lottery funding | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | date=29 September 2009 }} ===Awards and honours=== In 2009, Black won the first John Ivinson Award{{cite web|url=http://www.bcs.org/content/conWebDoc/32424|title=First BCS John Ivinson Award Goes to Dr Sue Black|publisher=[[British Computer Society]]|accessdate=16 July 2014}} from the [[British Computer Society]] at the [[Royal Society]] in London. In 2011, Black won the [[PepsiCo]] Women's Inspiration Award.{{Cite web |url=http://pepsicowin.com/2011/08/23/if-i-can-do-it-so-can-you…/ |title=PepsiCo Women's Inspiration Award Winner – If I can do it, so can you… |last=Black |first=Sue |date=23 August 2011 |publisher=PepsiCo WIN |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605031541/http://pepsicowin.com/2011/08/23/if-i-can-do-it-so-can-you%E2%80%A6/ |archive-date=5 June 2012 |access-date=7 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 2012, she was listed as one of ''[[Datamation]]''{{'}}s 10 Women in Tech Who Give Back.{{cite web| url=http://www.datamation.com/feature/women-in-tech-who-give-back.html | title=10 Women in Tech Who Give Back | first=Jessica | last=Vartabedian | publisher=[[Datamation]] | date=6 August 2012 | accessdate=7 January 2016 }} Black was also one of the 30 women identified in the British Computer Society's Women in IT Campaign in 2014, who were then featured in the e-book "Women in IT: Inspiring the next generation" produced by the BCS.{{cite book|title=Women in IT: Inspiring the next generation|date=1 October 2014|publisher=British Computer Society|isbn=978-1-78017-287-3|page=57|url=http://www.bcs.org/upload/pdf/women-it.pdf|accessdate=14 October 2014}} In 2015, Black was identified as the 7th{{cite web|url = http://www.computerweekly.com/photostory/4500249403/Top-50-Most-Influential-Women-in-UK-IT-2015/7/7-Sue-Black-Founder-Techmums-Bletchley-Park-campaigner|website = Computer Weekly|accessdate = 11 July 2015|title = The 50 most influential women in UK IT 2015}} Most Influential Women in UK IT 2015, by ''[[Computer Weekly]]''. She was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2016 New Year Honours]] for services to technology.{{London Gazette|issue=61450|supp=y|page=N11|date=30 December 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-35202667|title=OBE for Bletchley campaigner Sue Black|last=Cellan-Jones|first=Rory|date=30 December 2015|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=30 December 2015}}{{Cite web|title = New Year's Honours 2016: CSV|url = https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/489050/NewYearHonoursList2016.csv/preview|publisher = Government of the United Kingdom|accessdate = 30 December 2015|date = 30 December 2015|series = New Year's Honours 2016}} Black was awarded the 2017 [[Social Impact Abie Award]] from the [[AnitaB.org]].{{cite web|url=https://anitab.org/profiles/abie-award-winners/social-impact/sue-black/|title=Dr. Sue Black OBE - AnitaB.org|date=1 August 2017|publisher=anitab.org|accessdate=14 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://anitab.org/awards-grants/abie-awards/|title=ABIE Awards - AnitaB.org|publisher=anitab.org|accessdate=14 November 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Black, Sue}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of London South Bank University]] [[Category:Academics of London South Bank University]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Westminster]] [[Category:Academics of University College London]] [[Category:Software engineering researchers]] [[Category:English computer scientists]] [[Category:English bloggers]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Computer Society]] [[Category:Bletchley Park people]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Arts]] [[Category:Women bloggers]] [[Category:21st-century women scientists]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Bletchley Park women]] [[Category:People from Fareham]] [[Category:British women computer scientists]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox person |image = Tej_Bahadur_Chitrakar.jpg |caption = Tej Bahadur in his early twenties | parents = Shiva Das Chitrakar
Aasha Mati Chitrakar | spouse = Krishna Maya Chitrakar (m.1918 - death.1936)
Mana Keshari Chitrakar (m.1940 until death) | relatives = Vishnudas Chitrakar (Grandfather)
Dilbahadur Chitrakar (Nephew) |birth_date = 1898 |birth_place = Haugal, [[Lalitpur District, Nepal|Lalitpur]], [[Nepal]] |death_date = 1971 |death_place = Tanlacchi, [[Kathmandu]], [[Nepal]] }} '''Tej Bahadur Chitrakar''' ([[Devanagari]]: तेज बहादुर चित्रकार; 1898-1971) was a Nepalese artist who had a prolific artistic career in the early 20th century. He was one of the leaders in the development of contemporary art in Nepal in the early 20th century. Chitrakar spearheaded the trend of creating art using new techniques for its aesthetic value, and introduced a new style in the milieu of traditional art which is essentially religious and follows descriptions laid down in ancient texts.''Images of a Lifetime--: A Historical Perspective'', 20 November-5 December 2005, Siddhartha Art Gallery, 2005{{cite web|url=http://www.siddharthaartgallery.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=70&Itemid=11|title=History|author=Administrator|work=siddharthaartgallery.com}}{{cite web|url=http://nepalitimes.com/news.php?id=2051#.VOddhy7RNLE|title=Giving their art and soul|publisher=Nepali Times|accessdate=20 February 2015}} ==Personal== Tej Bahadur was born in [[Lalitpur District, Nepal|Lalitpur]] as a second son to Shivadas and Ashamati in the [[chitrakar]] caste of [[Newar]] community. The caste [[chitrakar]] were traditionally entrusted by the state or the Malla ruler as sole custodian of tradition of religious paintings in the valley since 14th century AD. The extraordinary family background and his own talent since his early childhood led him to the Government college of Fine Art in 1918 at Calcutta (now Kolkata) as one of the earliest Nepali to receive the degree in Fine Art with distinction in portraiture in Oil in 1927. His education was sponsored by the then prime minister Chandra Shumsher. He returned to Nepal in 1929 AD. He heralded a change in Nepalese art scene from traditional religious art to modern Western-style paintings. He also began teaching art at Durbar High School and later became head of Juddha Art SchoolMadan Chitrakar, Tej Bahadur Chitrakar Icon of a Transition, TeBaChi Studies Center, 2004, {{ISBN|9789993387978}}{{cite web|url=http://artnepal.net/lalitkala|title=Lalit Kala Campus|work=artnepal.net}} He initiated 'Chitrakala Udhyog Sangh' (now defunct) to promote Nepali art. Many of his enduring paintings today are in the collection of prestigious Art galleries worldwide. ==Honors== In 2009, the Postal Services Department, Government of Nepal issued a commemorative postage stamp (Denomination - Rs. 15) depicting a portrait of Tej Bahadur Chitrakar to honor his contribution to the development of art in Nepal.{{cite web |url=http://www.mediabd.com/newissue/fdc_details.php?country_id=3&entry_id=46&page=3 |title=New Issue :: View FDC Details :: Nepal :: Tej Bahadur Chitrakar (1898-1971 )|author=Mosharaf Husain |work=mediabd.com}} [[File:First_day_cover_Tej_bahadur_Chitrakar_Nepal.jpg|thumb|right|First Day cover of stamps commemorating Tej Bahadur Chitrakar's contributions]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chitrakar, Tej Bahadur}} [[Category:1971 deaths]] [[Category:Nepalese artists]] [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:Nepalese people]] [[Category:Newar]] [[Category:People from Kathmandu]]

revision.text:
'''Thaddeus Strassberger''' (born 1976) is an American [[opera director]] and [[scenic designer]]. In 2005 he was awarded the European Opera Directing Prize by [[Opera Europa]] for his work on [[Opera Ireland]]'s production of [[Rossini]]'s ''[[La Cenerentola]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.metoperafamily.org/operanews/issue/article.aspx?id=5291&issueID=336|title=Mending Meyerbeer|work=[[Opera News]]|date=August 2009 |volume=74 |issue=2|accessdate=August 6, 2009}} ==Biography== Born to parents of [[Cherokee and German]] descent, Strassberger grew up in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]]. He graduated from [[Booker T. Washington High School (Tulsa, Oklahoma)|Booker T. Washington High School]] in 1994. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree from [[The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art]] in [[New York City]]. He won a [[Fulbright Fellowship]] which enabled him to study at [[La Scala]] in [[Milan]] in 2000-2001 where he graduated from the ''Accademia della Scala'' with a Diploma in Scenic Design Realisation. During the first several years of his career he worked as an assistant director for opera productions at the [[Teatro di San Carlo]] in [[Naples]], [[La Fenice]] in [[Venice]], the [[Teatro Lirico di Cagliari|Teatro Lirico]] in [[Cagliari]], the [[Badisches Staatstheater Karlsruhe]], the [[Houston Grand Opera]], [[Pittsburgh Opera]], [[Michigan Opera Theatre]], and [[Santa Fe Opera]] among others. ===Career as opera director=== In 2005 Strassberger directed a new production of [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s ''[[Rigoletto]]'' for [[Opera Colorado]] and restaged the Badisches Staatstheater's production of [[Michael Nyman]]'s ''[[Man and Boy: Dada]]'' at the [[National Theatre (Prague)|National Theatre]] in [[Prague]]. In 2007 he directed the rarely mounted [[Rossini]] opera ''[[La gazzetta]]'' at the [[Rossini in Wildbad]] Festival, a production which was recorded by [[Naxos Records]] for release on DVD starring Michael Spyres. That same year he was the director and scenic designer for the [[Lyric Opera of Kansas City]]'s production of ''[[Aida]]'', [[Theater Augsburg]]'s production of [[Christoph Willibald Gluck]]'s ''[[Orfeo ed Euridice]]'', and [[Hessisches Staatstheater Wiesbaden]]'s mounting of ''La Cenerentola''. In 2008 Strassberger was the director for [[Wolf Trap Opera]]'s production of [[Richard Strauss]]'s ''[[Ariadne auf Naxos]]'' and was the director and scenic designer for [[Opéra de Montréal]]'s production of [[Giacomo Puccini]]'s ''[[La Fanciulla del West]]'', and [[Arizona Opera]]'s production of ''[[La traviata]]''. He also served as the director for Arizona Opera's mounting of [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]'s ''[[The Magic Flute]]'', an opera he had previously directed at both [[Utah Opera]] and [[Madison Opera]] in 2006. During the 2009-2010 season, Strassberger directed Mozart's ''[[Le nozze di Figaro]]'' at the [[Norwegian National Opera]], [[Giacomo Meyerbeer]]'s ''[[Les Huguenots]]'' at the [[Bard SummerScape Festival]], and [[Hector Berlioz]]'s ''[[Les nuits d'été]]'' at [[Opera Azuriales]]. He also worked as both director and scenic designer for Puccini's ''[[Turandot]]'' at Theater Augsburg and [[Ambroise Thomas]]'s ''[[Hamlet (opera)|Hamlet]]'' at the [[Washington National Opera]] conducted by [[Plácido Domingo]]. In 2010-2011, he returned to the Norwegian National Opera to direct and design ''[[The Rape of Lucretia]]'' and made his Austrian debut with the [[Tyrolean State Theatre|Tiroler Landestheater]] with a new production of ''[[La fanciulla del West]]'', while in 2012 he directed ''[[Nabucco]]'' for the Washington National Opera, a production which has subsequently been seen in Philadelphia, Minnesota, Montreal, Miami and in 2017 with the LA Opera, starring Liudmyla Monastyrska, [[Plácido Domingo]], and Morris Robinson, conducted by James Conlon.{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-opera-nabuco-review-20171016-story.html|title=With Plácido Domingo and L.A. Opera, 'Nabucco' still has the power to provoke|date=2017-10-15|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} In 2016, he directed the premiere of [[David T. Little]] and [[Royce Vavrek]]'s opera [[JFK (opera)|JFK]] for the Fort Worth Opera, a co-commission with l'Opera de Montreal.{{Cite web|url=http://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2016/5/Reviews/FORT_WORTH__JFK.html|title=OPERA NEWS - JFK|website=www.operanews.com|access-date=2016-06-25}} His work with [[Bard SummerScape|Bard Summerscape]] in the New York's Hudson Valley comprises six important revivals or North American premieres: 2009 - ''Les Huguenots''{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2018/10/22/the-dark-prophetic-vision-of-giacomo-meyerbeer|title=The Dark, Prophetic Vision of Giacomo Meyerbeer|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en-US}} 2010 - ''Der ferne Klang''{{Cite web|url=https://www.therestisnoise.com/2010/07/der-ferne-klang-clintonera-production.html|title=Der ferne Klang (Clinton-era staging)|website=Alex Ross: The Rest Is Noise|access-date=2018-11-01}} 2012 - ''Le roi malgré lui'' {{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/31/arts/music/le-roi-malgre-lui-at-fisher-center-for-the-performing-arts.html|title=‘Le Roi Malgré Lui’ at Fisher Center for the Performing Arts|last=Smith|first=Steve|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en}} 2013 - ''The Oresteia''{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324809004578635842420975424|title=Russian in Nature, Greek at Its Roots|last=Waleson|first=Heidi|date=2013-07-30|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} 2015 - ''The Wreckers'' {{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/28/arts/music/review-the-wreckers-a-tale-of-piracy-love-and-betrayal.html|title=Review: ‘The Wreckers,’ a Tale of Piracy, Love and Betrayal|last=Fonseca-wollheim|first=Corinna Da|date=2015-07-27|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-06-25}} 2018 - ''Demon''{{Cite web|url=http://fishercenter.bard.edu/summerscape/|title=Bard SummerScape|website=fishercenter.bard.edu|access-date=2017-11-15}} In 2014, he directed ''Satyagraha'', the first ever opera by Philip Glass to be produced in Russia, at the [http://uralopera.ru/ Ekaterinburg State Academic Opera]. The production was nominated for five [http://www.goldenmask.ru/ Golden Mask Awards], including 'Best Production' and 'Best Director'.http://www.goldenmask.ru/fest.php?year=22&area=169 It won the 2016 Critics' Prize for Best Director and additionally the production won the prize for Best Chorus.{{Cite web|url=http://eng.goldenmask.ru/gm.php?id=127|title=Winners 2016|website=eng.goldenmask.ru|access-date=2016-06-25}} Also in Ekaterinburg, his production of Weinberg's The Passenger was the first to be performed in the original Russian edition. It has been nominated for four Golden Mask Awards, including 'Best Production' and 'Best Director.' {{Cite web|url=http://www.goldenmask.ru/fest_24_183.html|title=ЗОЛОТАЯ МАСКА - ФЕСТИВАЛЬ И ПРЕМИЯ|website=Golden Mask|access-date=2017-11-15}} His Royal Opera House Covent Garden production of ''I due Foscari'' starring Plácido Domingo, Maria Agresta, and Francesco Meli and conductor by [[Antonio Pappano|Sir Antonio Pappano]] is available on DVD.{{Cite web|url=https://www.roh.org.uk/productions/i-due-foscari-by-thaddeus-strassberger|title=I due Foscari — Productions — Royal Opera House|website=www.roh.org.uk|access-date=2018-11-01}} It was a co-production with Los Angeles Opera, Palau de les Arts Reina Sofía, Valencia, and Theater an der Wien. '''His approach to the repertoire''' Opera News magazine featured Strassberger in its '[https://www.operanews.com/Opera_News_Magazine/2012/8/Features/Thaddeus_Strassberger.html Next Wave' feature] in August 2012.
"Strauss and Hofmannsthal, Verdi and Solera — even going back to da Ponte and Mozart — you feel as if everyone is in this constant state of gloom and doom: the theaters are shutting down next year, the quality isn't what it was, we don't have the voices we used to have. When Verdi presented the score of ''Nabucco'' to Bartolomeo Merelli, they said, 'There's no budget.' Verdi said, 'I've got Strepponi and the whole cast,' and they said, 'You'll have to use sets from the warehouse,' and Verdi said, 'That's all right. Let's get it onstage.' That's no different from an American company saying you have to rub two sticks together to get the production on because our NEA budget got cut this year."
In the June 2012 issue of the British magazine, ''Opera'', which examines recent repertoire trends which reveal a move towards the rare and unusual, Strassberger makes the following observation regarding the staging of some of them: :"I love these works and they give me the freedom to turn up as a director and put them on stage without having to un-engineer what people thought they were going to be. The audience can focus on what they are experiencing rather than making comparisons with the past."Yehudi Shapiro, "Rarity Value", ''Opera'' (London), June 2012. Vol. 63, No. 6 ===Work with opera singer training programs=== Strassberger has also served on the staffs of several programs for opera singers in training. In 2006 he joined the faculty of the [[International Vocal Arts Institute]] (IIVA) in [[Tel Aviv]] where he directed the school's opera productions for two years. He has also directed operas at the IIVA in [[Chiari, Lombardy]], [[Italy]] and for the [[Opera Theatre of Lucca]]. In 2019, he works with Banff Centre's Opera in the 21st Century{{Cite news|url=https://www.banffcentre.ca/programs/opera-21st-century-instrumentalists/20190603|title=Opera in the 21st Century: Instrumentalists|access-date=2018-11-01|language=en}} developing new work with [[Paola Prestini]] and [[Royce Vavrek]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.tstrassberger.com Official website] *[http://operalively.com/forums/content.php/514-Exclusive-Interview-with-Thaddeus-Strassberger-stage-director Extensive interview with Strassberger on Opera Lively] *[http://articles.boston.com/2010-08-02/ae/29290339_1_schreker-opera-austrian-composer-franz-schreker-los-angeles-opera Jeremy Eichler, "‘Distant Sound’ resonates anew: Schreker opera from 1912 in US premiere", ''Boston Globe'', August 02, 2010] ''Der Ferne Klang'' review *[http://oslopuls.aftenposten.no/kunst_scene/article492430.ece ''The Rape of Lucrettia'' review] (in Norwegian) {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Strassberger, Thaddeus}} [[Category:1976 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American scenic designers]] [[Category:Booker T. Washington High School (Tulsa, Oklahoma) alumni]] [[Category:American opera directors]] [[Category:Cooper Union alumni]] [[Category:Fulbright Scholars]] [[Category:Cherokee people]] [[Category:Artists from Tulsa, Oklahoma]] [[Category:American theatre directors]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2009}} {{Infobox Officeholder |name=Wang Guangmei |native_name= {{nobold|王光美}} |native_name_lang = zh-hans |image=Wang Kwangmei, 1949 (cropped).jpg |imagesize= |caption = Wang Guangmei, in 1949. |order=[[Spouse of the President of the People's Republic of China]] |term=27 April 1959 – 21 October 1968 |president=[[Liu Shaoqi]] |predecessor=[[Jiang Qing]] |successor=[[Lin Jiamei]] |birth_date={{birth date|1921|9|26|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Tianjin]], [[Republic of China (1912-1949)|China]] |death_date={{death date and age|2006|10|13|1921|9|26|df=y}} |death_place=[[Beijing]], China |spouse=[[Liu Shaoqi]]
(m. 1948–1969; his death) |children=[[Liu Yuan (general)|Liu Yuan]]
Liu Pingping |relatives=[[Wang Guangying]] (brother) |alma_mater=[[Fu Jen Catholic University]] (Beijing) }} {{Chinese name|[[Wang (surname)|Wang]]}} '''Wang Guangmei''' ({{zh|c=王光美|p=Wáng Guāngmĕi|w=Wang Kuang-mei}}; 26 September 1921 – 13 October 2006) was a Chinese politician, philanthropist and the wife of [[Liu Shaoqi]], who served as the [[President of the People's Republic of China]] from 1959 to 1968. ==Life== ===Early years=== Wang Guangmei was born in 1921, and grew up in a distinguished and prominent Chinese family. Her father was a government minister and a diplomat; her mother was an educator. She studied [[French language|French]], [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[English language|English]], learning to speak all three, and earned a degree in physics from the [[Fu Jen Catholic University|Catholic University of Peking]] in Beijing. She also studied at an American missionary university, and was described as a sophisticated woman. In the mid-1940s, Wang Guangmei traveled to the Communist Party headquarters in [[Yan'an]] and served as an interpreter during efforts by the American statesman [[George Marshall]] to negotiate a truce between the Nationalist government and the Communist rebels. At this occasion, she gained the admiration of many Americans, which would later play a role in charges that she was an American spy. There, at the age of 24, she met [[Liu Shaoqi]], who was nearly twice her age and had previously been married on five occasions. For years she served as his secretary, and he was named a key deputy to Chairman [[Mao Zedong]] after the Communists took power in 1949. In 1959, Liu was named [[President of the People's Republic of China|Chinese President]], making him the second-most powerful man in the country. ===First lady=== After Liu became president in 1959, Wang became a very visible diplomatic companion to him. Wang Guangmei became once widely known in China as its beautiful, articulate, sophisticated first lady. In the early 1960s, the couple traveled abroad on state visits to [[Kingdom of Afghanistan|Afghanistan]], [[Burmese Way to Socialism|Burma]], [[Pakistan]] and [[Indonesia]]. In 1963, she joined a work team investigating corruption in the countryside, a mounting problem after the [[Great Leap Forward]], Mao's development programme of 1958–61. ===Cultural Revolution=== Liu and his wife became targets of the [[Cultural Revolution]], instigated by Chairman Mao. In mid-1966, when Mao's [[Red Guards (China)|Red Guards]] erupted into prominence — and Liu and other leaders tried to fathom what Mao had in mind — Wang headed a work team to restore order among the students at Beijing's [[Tsinghua University]]. The effort backfired when she came under attack by a militant opponent who accused her of being a counterrevolutionary. Her husband was also under fire by Mao and his deputies for being the leading "[[capitalist roader]]". Wang Guangmei's public role had also antagonized Mao's wife [[Jiang Qing]], who was growing politically ambitious. In April 1967, at Jiang's instigation, the Red Guards forced Wang to put on a tight-fitting [[qipao]] dress she had worn at a banquet in Indonesia, with silk stockings, high heels and a mocking necklace made out of [[table tennis|ping-pong]] balls, as proof of her bourgeoise, counterrevolutionary attitude.{{sfnp|Lawrence|2004|p=198}}https://internalreference.com/crimes-of-fashion-56d6fd77b38c The disgraced President Liu died in prison. Wang was put under house arrest, then imprisoned. Her four children were also punished. Imprisoned in [[Qincheng Prison]] during the cultural revolution, Wang was kept in ignorance of her family's fate. After four years, her children plucked up the courage to ask Mao for permission to see their parents. It was through his terse consent, "Their father is dead but they may see the mother", that Wang learned of her husband's death. Wang spent about 12 years in prison, and was released in 1979 — just before Mao's widow Jiang Qing and her [[Gang of Four]], who were blamed for the excesses of the Cultural Revolution, were put on trial. ===Later years=== Soon, Liu's reputation was rehabilitated, and Wang received compensation for her suffering during the Cultural Revolution. In 1980, she appeared in court during the trial of the Gang of Four as a victim of Jiang Qing's prosecution. Later, Wang was elected a permanent member of the National People's Political Consultative Conference. She founded the "Hope Project", a program aimed at aiding the poor throughout China. She even donated some of her family's valuable antiques, a few dating back to the Qing and Song dynasties, to charity. Wang died on October 13, 2006, at the No. 305 Military Hospital in Beijing. Her funeral was held at the [[Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery|Babaoshan Revolutionary Martyrs' Cemetery]] in Beijing on October 21, 2006. ==Family== Wang is survived by four children, some of whom have risen to prominent positions. Her eldest son, retired Gen. [[Liu Yuan (politician)|Liu Yuan]], was a prominent officer in the People's Liberation Army. Her daughter Liu Ting graduated from [[Boston University]] and [[Harvard Business School]], and is chairman and president of the Asia Link Group, consultants in corporate finance. ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== *{{cite book |last1=Lawrence |first1=Alan |title=China Since 1919 - Revolution and Reform: A Sourcebook |location=London and New York |publisher=Routledge |date=2004 |isbn=0-415-25142-7 }} *{{cite book |last1=Salisbury |first1=Harrison E |title=The New Emperors |location=New York |publisher=Avon Books |date=1992 |isbn=0-380-72025-6 }} ==External links== *[http://www.chinavitae.com/biography_display.php?id=539 Short Biography] on ''chinavitae.com'' *[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/17/obituaries/17wang.html?ex=1318737600&en=58691245f80dce18&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland&emc=rss "Wang Guangmei, 85, Dies; Former First Lady of China"], [[The New York Times]], October 17, 2006 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927010509/http://chinadigitaltimes.net/test_tag.php?id=wang%20guangmei Wang Guangmei on China Digital Times] *[https://www.theguardian.com/china/story/0,,1926880,00.html Wang Guangmei on Guardian Unlimited] {{s-start}} {{s-hon}} {{succession box| before=[[Jiang Qing]]| title=[[Spouse of the President of the People's Republic of China]]| years=1959–1968 | after=[[He Lianying]] }} {{s-end}} {{China First Ladies}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wang, Guangmei}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Liu Shaoqi family]] [[Category:Communist Party of China politicians from Tianjin]] [[Category:People of the Cultural Revolution]] [[Category:Spouses of national leaders]] [[Category:Fu Jen Catholic University alumni]] [[Category:Victims of the Cultural Revolution]] [[Category:Republic of China politicians from Tianjin]] [[Category:People's Republic of China politicians from Tianjin]]

{{About|the brewer and financier|the American inventor|William Gould Dow|the cricketer|Bill Dow (cricketer)}} [[File:William Dow.jpg|thumb|William Dow]] '''William Dow''' (March 27, 1800 – December 7, 1868) was a British-born brewer and financier of [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada.
Born at [[Muthill]], [[Perthshire]], he was the eldest son of Dr William Dow (1765-1844), [[Brewmaster]], and Anne Mason. Since 1652, his family had been brewing in [[Perthshire]]. Having gained an extensive experience in brewing under his father, he emigrated to Montreal, [[Lower Canada]] from [[Scotland]] in about 1818. He was employed as foreman of Thomas Dunn's brewery in Montreal and quickly became a partner. His younger brother, Andrew, who had also trained as a brewer, joined him, and on the death of Dunn, the company became known as ''William Dow and Company'', later known as [[Dow Breweries]]. It soon was a strong competitor to [[Molson]]'s, the biggest brewery in the city. Dow was also a [[financier]] and in 1860 he built his home, ''Strathearn House'', in Montreal's [[Golden Square Mile]].
== External links == * [http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=4404 Biography at ''the Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online''] * [http://www.imtl.org/montreal/building/Maison-William-Dow.php William Dow House, Montreal] * [http://www.lib.uwo.ca/programs/companyinformationcanada/ccc-dow.htm Business and History - Dow Brewery Limited]

{{Infobox Congressman |name = Zadock Pratt |image = Zadock Pratt clean.jpg |alt = An engraving of Zadock Pratt. |state = [[New York (state)|New York]] |district = [[New York's 8th congressional district|8th]] |term_start = March 4, 1837 |term_end = March 3, 1839 |predecessor = [[Aaron Vanderpoel]] |successor = [[Archibald L. Linn]] |state2 = [[New York (state)|New York]] |district2 = [[New York's 11th congressional district|11th]] |term_start2 = March 4, 1843 |term_end2 = March 3, 1845 |predecessor2 = [[Aaron Vanderpoel]] |successor2 = [[John F. Collin]] |state_senate3 = New York |birth_date = {{birth date|1790|10|30|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Stephentown]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1871|4|5|1790|10|30}} |death_place = [[Jersey City]], [[New Jersey]] |restingplace = [[Prattsville, New York|Prattsville]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |restingplacecoordinates = {{coord|42|19|14|N|74|26|7|W|display=inline}} |birthname = Zadock Pratt Jr. |nationality = [[United States|American]] |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |spouse = Beda Dickerman (m. 1818, d. 1819)
